fJzNJMGcNrrAqnliYkyWrA.text: biggest virtue is that it doesn't feel like it's part of the station. service is a little confused between the bar and table but everyone was friendly. starters felt overdear but the main courses are excellent. It actually makes waiting for a train from King's Cross a pleasurable way to spend the afternoon

YujEz3-0dqI97Y0JP8A1Xw.text: I would like this place a lot better if I hadn't tried the food. The pub is conveniently located inside King's Cross so you can grab a pint while you wait for the train. It's got an old-timey Victorian feel which I'm guessing is replicated and not genuine, but even so they've done a good job of it and it feels really cozy and atmospheric inside. Even the toilets have old-fashioned pull handles on the top.However, the food is not as interesting as everything else. I got the fish and chips and hubby got a chicken and leek pie. Both were okay standard pub food. Not bad but nothing special - probably not home made but reheated from whatever central location they send stuff out to the Fullers chain pubs. The fish/chips came with tartar sauce but no salt or vinegar. We even had to snag someone to get some ketchup. The fish was pretty heavily breaded and little oily. Like I said, what you'd expect from mediocre fish/chips. The chicken/leek pie came with mashed potatoes but no gravy. Very dry potatoes. Not enough liquid in the pie to make up for it. Why would you send out mashed potatoes without gravy? Not impressed.Like I said, drinks only - 4 stars, food - 2 stars.

B0g-jdj18H7Ei-jy7PguFA.text: Very disappointed. When we walked in, no one greeted us. We saw a server but she ignored us and didn't return, so we walked back to the bar and asked if there was somewhere we should be waiting or if we should seat ourselves. The reply was, "If you want." So we sat down and waited. The same server passed us several more times but never greeted or acknowledged us at all, even when I made an effort to politely catch her eye. We sat there for about 20 minutes with no service or greeting until we finally gave up and left. We went to the wine bar across the street and they served us immediately. I see that this restaurant gets good reviews, so maybe this was an off day? It wasn't just bad service, it was *no* service. We won't be returning.

0bFN7eOLKxastZiE0se16w.text: I've rarely been so torn on deciding a rating. The parcel yard is a station gem. For someone who has spent their formative years in New Street's dingey Shakespeare and Euston's pokey Doric Arch, the airy atrium, abundance of seating and decent beer choice were an unexpected breath of fresh air. So as I walked in I was set on 5* but oh the service...At 3pm bar staff outnumbered punters 5 to 1, so being ignored for 5 mins wasn't the greatest. It's not the first time that's ever happened to me but it was the first time I've ever been ignored while being served. It is a rare skill to be able to communicate without looking at someone and only using 7 words, but this guy managed it with aplomb. The beer was tasty but at £5.40 a pint was just expensive enough to make this a 3* review.My advice would be to give this place a go and hope that the poor service was a one off...but don't bank on it.

12_pVsT-789HgDIHDZOJ-A.text: A surprisingly good venue for a catch up. It's large inside with lots of different spaces and there were all sorts of people inside when we visited at 6:30pm on a Wednesday evening....lone drinkers, family groups, friends and workmates. Quite loud and clearly a place to sit and drink and talk, socialise and reminisce as your train pulls out of the station!

cMX3d5e4lMteaUgpouJP1w.text: Have been in here for weekend lunch a couple of times. Really convenient for anyone coming in to King's Cross on a train. Serves a decent range of 'pub grub' done right, including a Sunday Roast. A favourite is the chicken, ham & leek pie but I've found all the food to be above standard (even the husband, who avoids 'gastropubs' at all costs likes it here)There's a number of different seating areas, so I've always been able to find a table when going in, but it's a fairly popular place and busy (noisy) at standard meal times. Some areas appear to have table service (at least the area we sat in one Sunday did), and this services proved friendly, if a teeny bit haphazard. The prices aren't the cheapest, but then in London where is? (No seriously, if you know somewhere cheap and good, tell me!)I would happily return here as it's convenient, but it's not necessarily somewhere I would go far out of my way to visit.

IKMJJEdckqd7u_3i3VG8Sg.text: Have you ever had time to kill at King's Cross and thought "What should I do now?"Are you a fan of cask ales?Have you ever just missed a train and realized you had about 30 minutes to waste (like we did when I forced people to take the bus instead of the Tube and it took much longer than anticipated)?The Parcel Yard is ideal for you. It's located right next to platforms 9-11 (which is great for me as that is usually where my trains leave from). You may now know it's there as you have to go up some stairs.I expected The Parcel Yard to be small and lame. Boy was I wrong. There's a huge pub there with "outdoor" seating. There are a bunch of small rooms to hang out for a bit of privacy as well. There is also a digital display showing when the trains are leaving so you don't miss your train.The decor looks kind of classic British pub. Everything is made of wood! They also had six(!!!) cask ales on draught to choose from. While most of them were Fullers (as it is a Fullers pub), there were some guest ales as well. But it's not often you find that many cask ales available! We only got one pint as we only had a half an hour to kill and they actually were closing up around 11:30 as well.I was thoroughly pleased and surprised at my visit to the Parcel Yard and will definitely come back! Maybe if I have enough to drink I can go downstairs and make a fool out of myself at the nearby Platform 9 3/4...

OXZ3f3eJADGcCcMm6JBxWw.text: This cosy Fullers pub inside Kings Cross station is housed in the original parcel yard - hence the name - and has up-cycled trolleys, suitcases, and coat racks all around as tables and storage for your bags while you wait for your train.  There are numerous rooms, some are available for private hire, including an area with indoor trees and a view of the sky, two floors above.  The ale is well kept, the bar snacks are traditional with a twist and excellent; triple-cooked chips, pork scratchings, posh pork pie, and pigs in blankets. The menus are seasonal but stick to the English gastro-pub theme making it well worth coming back to try something new.It's such a nice pub that we don't rush for trains any more as we'll rather pop in for a swift-half, take our time, and get the next one.

CySnJcBr2cuiFQ1y3yzhNQ.text: The Parcel Yard is a surprisingly comfy pub right inside the station.I love the Fuller's beers they have on tap, so that's a plus, especially since they often have a guest ale on.Food is solid and consistent in quality; better than your average pub grub at any rate.

qmIplR3i3ILVrSU-sN8T5Q.text: Excellent pub for an after hours pint. Great selection of Fullers ales plus a couple of guests, well kept and worthy of a mention by CAMRA. Comfortable and spacious arranged on 2 floors around a central courtyard, thats light and airy ideal for watching sport on the large flat screen.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom

-VqjsFTRrNt16yeZLCn58g.text: Cute place, friendly host, quick service, free wifi - mediocre food. This place is probably better for drinks than food.

2B8pww8bLKmKOeeEaSb89w.text: The Kings Cross station has seen quite a renovation, and though there are still plenty of fast food options to tempt the hungry traveler, look a little closer and you'll find some stairs leading to The Parcel Yard, an out-of-the-way Fuller's pub that serves as a nice respite from the hustle of the rest of the station. Take a breath, grab a bite from a pretty tempting-looking menu, and watch the monitors for information on your train. Make sure you actually remember to catch your proper train, though - the relaxing vibes from the pub can be deceptive.

7vQ1y1wb3RS0tVaaAMMyeg.text: We visited the newish Fullers pub located up some stairs on the first floor by the Watermark bookshop entrance, in the old parcel depot, at the revamped Kings Cross station. The atmosphere was 10/10, the beer selection creative and tasty...but the food wowed us! A pub lunch of potted shrimps, salt beef sandwich, Cornish crab baked with a salad, roast beef and a roast pork sandwich...all for about 25 quid!!!The food was sensational, the setting unique, the toilets well kept, creatively designed and CLEAN...the staff chatty and helpful. This was not how I remembered Kings Cross station from the 1980's with it's stale sandwiches and weak British rail tea......the new design of the station building is to use the most overused 'Americanisim'....AWESOME! It mixes the old with the newGo eat and drink.......you will not be disappointed.

tyKTxyi_gAC-JN_F_vmVnw.text: A solid Fuller's outpost. Located upstairs in Kings Cross Station, this place has around 10 casks of mostly Fuller's but also a few other breweries, plus standard kegs and a few decent bottles. There are several rooms to this pub, including a dining area, a sunlight patio, some rooms with living room feel to them. Interesting. Serviceable staff. Average pricing. Probably not a destination pub but a damn fine option if you are looking to kill time while in the Station.

NBbB5ZA7Jaxjhr8y2D70DA.text: Well fitted out, very good food for the price (huge portions), good drink selection, niceynice staff! The only place to go when you need a pint of Fullers and you're stuck in Kings Cross Station.

QbaIlRCp7zmT59W-ITYKgQ.text: Great space earns this pub 4 stars. On entry it feels very large, with at least 3 decently sized rooms. Food is slight cut above the average and price is reasonable to expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom

wE2wfy7wKT_jE-vWvrz1xQ.text: With a keen location in King's Cross station, The Parcel Yard is a newly redone pub from a retrofitted parcel yard. I love the old history of the place and find that turning anything into a pub can be a brilliant idea. This new décor is inviting and my battered cod was delicious. The service was okay - not the best, but friendly enough. The brit hop tap and free wi-fi were definite benefits of the pub.

UtA98WmiqdlYEq3xqdwtzw.text: When I heard we were meeting friends at the pub in kings cross station, my heart sank. Memories of awful station pubs came flooding back and my feet felt like lead going up the stairs to the pub door. You can imagine my surprise then when this pub turned it to be really quite nice. Firstly it's huge so there are plenty of areas to stand or sit if you're not a footie fan and want to get away from the screens. Secondly the decor is really well thought out, original or repro thomas crapper toilets and basins (teehee), vintage waiting room and restroom signs, clean white tiling. This place is new, fresh and welcoming, I hope it stays that way, I'd hate to come back in a year's time and find it had gone the way of its predecessors...

N0aBc8QZ7Fj9OFrKCkw-Rg.text: Great for a pints after work, not so brilliant for food.Decor style is a la Restoration Hardware (Americans will know what I mean).or perhaps more descriptively, modern Victorian utility. Lots of wood, big comfy leather chairs and the odd wooden stool and low table, industrial-style light fixtures and big windows. Range of beers is great, and as the venue itself is big you don't feel so packed in like sweaty sardines, which is the norm in a lot of pubs in the Kings Cross area. The location is also fantastic when you need to meet up with people who commute to London: they can quickly stumble downstairs to the nearby train platforms, thereby lengthening total available drinking time.Now for the food: I've eaten once from the restaurant menu and once from the bar menu. I recommend the restaurant over the bar as the menu changes frequently, representing seasonal availability. I've had the butternut squash salad which was very good, but the portion was a bit small. I find choices on the bar menu far too fatty overall and provided in overpriced, small portions. I was very disappointed by the calamari rings, which were fried to death in a very heavy onion-ring batter which was greasy and overpowered the calamari entirely. My advice: Stick with the beer and have no fear.

44Y24Bc0YVCQuIeG51GXMw.text: Decent pub with decent ales considering it is in a railway station. Very busy. Great competition in the area since the redevelopment work, but still reasonably priced here.

c-reIiyf08X59hLqec344g.text: Lovely pub with an excellent selection of real ales. It's a good place for a stop off before hopping on your train home. Great!

1sXQ2DPbo3qRf2tuhyVFyQ.text: Very good.  We thought be in the station, it would be sub par but we were very pleased.

dkcki5VAc9pw9JGKdyDU8g.text: We were being super tourists and naturally were visiting Platform 9 3/4 when we decided to try the pub at the top of the stairs. The menu had fish and chips which is a must when in London. The chef's special was sausage and mashed, so my fiance and I decided to share both dishes to get our London food fix. We didn't know what to expect from pub food from a place located in a train station, but it was the best meal we have had in our 2 week trip in Europe. Everything was cooked perfectly. The fish was crispy, the sausage, gravy, and mashed were super flavorful. We even got daring and ordered the chicken wings and those were like American chicken wings. Don't expect to come here and get Coca-Cola because they only serve Pepsi. Biggest disappointment of this visit.

U-a7tLXhBwVsyYok9XP5Jw.text: Stopped by The Parcel Yard to grab dinner and drinks while out in Kings Cross. Beer selection was good, they had some higher gravity options which I was a fan of. For food we both ordered the Frontier-battered cod aka fish and chips and enjoyed it. Great spot!

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. Fish & Chips

N-hd7fpFIIcdmnrjERWArg.text: Great beer selection and the food was pretty awesome as well. Paid a little more since we were I. Kong's cross but it was fun watching the trains come in and out! We had a few rounds then ordered some food. My hubby opted for the burger (which was strange! I thought he'd go for the fish and chips again!) I got chicken schnitzel and it was soooo good!! We enjoyed our dinner and cocktails very much.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. My birthday boy!

cfvJN1cL9HetAAUokA9yFA.text: A really happening spot! Although I ended up having to interrupt a servers trot to get seated, once we were accommodated all was well. It was nice to finally sit down and enjoy our last English meal before we traveled on to our next destination. Had a great experience and that was all by chance I suppose; you see we were just at kings cross station to jump through platform 9 3/4 & check out the Harry Potter shop, but we needed to get some fish & chips as our last meal in London. So I searched for the closest Fish & Chips to us & thus The Parcel Yard popped up! Really, get the Battered Cod & Chips! It's HUGE

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. FISH & CHIPS with a side of Spring Pea Slaw #EUROtrippin2018 #EatWithAri #AriVidiVici #KingsCross #London
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. March2018 #EUROtrippin2018 #EatWithAri #AriVidiVici #KingsCrossStation #London #England
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. MEAT PIE #EUROtrippin2018 #EatWithAri #AriVidiVici #KingsCross #London

GUkFcimeZZBa5_cPlpDbyw.text: We went there after trip to Cambridge. The place has a nice atmosphere and service. I had a traditional fish and chips. It was good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom

-x4VulNbRQwT-r3Oe3Txmw.text: Large joint, with a few rooms to choose from. Good food. Sparse service. Probably one of the better places to eat in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom

UaBTGSXWs4cwKkVZPg4FCQ.text: This is a great pub!I loved the atmosphere here.  It has various rooms each with a different vibe.  It's cool that its a converted post office. On the evening we went there was a football game on and the mood was very fun and exciting! I could see myself spending many evenings here relaxing. Beer selection was awesome, great variety of different Fullers beers and I liked them all. I know we tried the honeydew (I wanted a little more flavor out of it), the seafarers, London Pride, and olivers island. My favorites were the London pride and olivers island. The food was also phenomenal!  I had the chicken, ham and leek pie. This was both of our favorites. The sauce was super yummy and had a lot of flavor. I could drink a pint of that sauce! Their fish and chips were also very solid and didn't taste like it had been frozen and thawed like it does at some pubs. Highly recommend for a fun time with a young crowd.

a1dqsFDo7y2QJ_nfwoR4nA.text: Ignore the pin on the map provided - The Parcel Yard is located in Kings Cross Station right next to the Harry Potter shop.I like this place - the service is fast, the food is fine, and the drinks are good. As a converted parcel office it's unique and I enjoyed looking around. The bar has lots of room to walk - just beware of going on the weekends as it's likely to be crowded with families and strollers.

xZk4dU1vjh5eq2FKVRyafg.text: We looking for a place for fish and chips and we were pleasantly surprised. The staff is friendly and helpful. Mashed peas were great! I can only give the fish a 7 out of 10 though. I did not waste any though...nice place to have a drink while waiting for your train! Service was very prompt.

nqoGHlJXMmU5taSz5aR49w.text: Ok, so it's not the world's greatest boozer but it does a very good job in difficult circumstances. It's a big bar and a meeting place for pretty much everyone in here. I'm sure Harry Potter meets his mates here now he's grown up. The beer here is good, the wine isn't bad and the food is obviously not great. Top tip - head to the top floor as it's less busier.

WaOfuXnNV4LH1PUDCZNKig.text: Very roomy pub located in the back of Kings Cross train station.  Unless you know where it is located, it is very easy to miss.  It is pretty large with a nice atrium in the center.  It is a nice place get pint before or after a train trip. Did not try the food but the plates going by me looked pretty good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom

S1kov2Uasiv47FBLGrkCLg.text: The Parcel Yard is a disused parcel sorting office converted into a Fullers pub. For a station bar, it is probably one of the best there is. Set at the back of the station, mean that you would not just pass it.Spread over two floors it has views across the King's Cross station platforms. It also has a really attractive indoor courtyard with a glass ceiling. It is tastefully furnished and retains the feel of being part of a station, as opposed to just a pub. There are lots of little rooms, as well as a seperate dining area, the atrium court, and the main bar. The Parcel Yard has a large selection of real ales, as you would normally find in a Fullers pub. It also serves up the standard pub menu with a mixture of gastropub type dishes. There are so any good places to eat in the area, I don't think I would make a point of eating here.If your at Kings Cross and looking for a pint, this place would be a good place to enjoy a drink. It's not the sort of place I would go out of my way for though, or somewhere I would look to enjoy an evening out.

XPlJOStA0GfQLiMqyfYpgQ.text: Hidden away in the corner of Kings Cross Station is a Fullers Pub. It looks like a small generic station bar from the outside, but climb the stairs (or take the lift) and what opens before you is a craft beer bar of note.It's reasonably priced and has a fair amount of room. The selection of beers is pretty good. On this occasion, I was only getting a quick drink but the selection of foods being served also looked excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. Busy bar on a Friday afternoon

rPTYREsmNmfjDPKftwG7fA.text: We passed by this place several times on our way to/from our flat in King's Cross during a recent stay in London. One night we were tired and looking for a pub to grab dinner at and saw that this place had good reviews on Yelp. We were glad we did.The "restaurant" is upstairs, so don't be put off if the downstairs if full of merry makers. The food is a notch above traditional pub food, would highly recommend.

NGMyCbu0vy6G0yOHaWaGGQ.text: A great addition to King's Cross railway station! A converted parcels office, The Parcel Yard is a Fuller's pub situated in a quiet corner of the station. It is a huge building on two levels and is very bright and airy. There is a large bar stocking various real ales, with several rooms off, ideal for groups or just a bit of privacy. There are good views over the station too.I would judge The Parcel Office one of the best station pubs I have visited and well worth a look if you have time before your train.

SoZYwwxPx5vTesg_wVtxMQ.text: Short and to the point for once, I've always discounted this place under the assumption it would be a grimy station pub... that couldn't be further from the truth! I wouldn't say that they have the most amazing drinks and food, but they definitely punch above what I had expected. It's actually quite nice inside (and clean!), and doesn't carry any of the station pub stigma that can come with such a place... highly recommended if you have a bit of time to kill in the station and would prefer a pub to the other offerings. There's normally plenty of room as well as the place is deceptively large. Depending on the time I had I would typically wander to somewhere a bit local, but now it's here... nice and close(ish) to the platforms, no need to venture further for a pint.

nTO7f9d5q5Vh9Ut-iL2vSQ.text: I was astonished by The Parcel Yard! Tucked away in the corner of Kings Cross station this pub is deceptive, inside it has 2 huge floors, loads of seating and a great selection of ales. What was most surprising is how comfortably quiet and reasonably priced it is for a station! The staff were fantastic, we sat upstairs and when they saw me head for the downstairs bar, which has the larger selection of beer, they offered to have my order sent up for me! I didn't eat here but I will next time I need a bite at Kings Cross station. They'll have a hard job beating Honest Burger which is just around the corner... But the staff and ale selection might just make up for it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. Upstairs
Photo of The Parcel Yard - London, United Kingdom. The upstairs bar

KZZ0JT9eIBaBTOuX87FI-g.text: I am def a fan of The Parcel Yard. Especially after I recently had the most filling butternut squash fritter salad with pomegranate seeds and avocado - delicious - so delicious I went back again for dinner with another friend just so I could have it again. Any place that has a good veggie option is a plus for me but from what I have seen of others food they seemed to like what they got. All looked like good pub food to me but not super dooper gastro pub stylie!!  The Parcel Yard is very close to home for me and I have popped in with friends for a quick drink, popped in for a quick meal with significant others and even booked an area to host a fancy dress Un-birthday party. The atmosphere is very classic waiting room style. there are little booths with sofas and tables, a bigger dining room area with various tables and chairs, quite low lighting but not low enough that you can't see, and you can look out from the windows down on to the trains too. There is also an upstairs with good floor space. Various chairs and tables and room for a small gathering!!On tap you will find an array of pints, a number from local brewers and speciality brewers too which is a bonus. Food prices are pretty reasonable and all in all it has always been a pleasant affair when I have visited. Staff are kind, we got a free drink when they thought they had taken too long with our dinner, which we didn't feel was a long time to wait but they offered so that was nice. There is table service in the dining room but you often have to grab the waiters attention to order quickly so if you are in a rush and a waiter hasn't seen you I would suggest going to the bar. All in all, definitely recommended whether you are killing time or are in the area for a quick visit. And it is next to Platform 9 3/4!!Enjoyxyz

AF87bxRMwoaERU-bGNHBtA.text: A large pub and eatery inside King's Cross station. The food was good and prices average, although not cheap as this is a premium location. The decor is  interesting.  Unfortunately the downside is that it can be overcrowded and hard to get a seat never mind a table. Recommended on an off peak day.
